qas.question: IASP's definition of pain includes what aspect as an essential part?
What is it possible to induce which is, contrary to expectations, devoid of unpleasantness?

answers.text: a state described as intense pain

qas.question: Which type of injection has caused patients to report they have pain but aren't bothered by it?
How much do some patients going through psychosurgery suffer from the sensation of pain?
What perspective towards pain are some people with perfectly normal nerves born with?
What is an essential part of the AISP definition of pain?
What is the result of psychosurgery injection?

context: Although <a0_0><b5_0>unpleasantness<b5_0/><a0_0/> is an essential part of the IASP definition of pain, it is possible to induce <a1_0>a state described as <b6_0>intense pain<a1_0/> devoid of unpleasantness<b6_0/> in some patients, with <a2_0>morphine<a2_0/> injection or psychosurgery. Such patients report that they have pain but are not bothered by it; they recognize the sensation of pain but suffer <a3_0>little, or not at all<a3_0/>. <a4_0><b7_0>Indifference<a4_0/> to pain<b7_0/> can also rarely be present from birth; these people have normal nerves on medical investigations, and find pain unpleasant, but do not avoid repetition of the pain stimulus.
